\w á¼©|strong="G3588"\w* \w Ï‡Î¬ÏÎ¹Ï‚|strong="G5485"\w* \w Î¼ÎµÏ„á½°|strong="G3326"\w* \w Ï€Î¬Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½|strong="G3956"\w* \w Ï„á¿¶Î½|strong="G3588"\w* \w á¼€Î³Î±Ï€ÏÎ½Ï„Ï‰Î½|strong="G0025"\w* \w Ï„á½¸Î½|strong="G3588"\w* \w ÎšÏÏÎ¹Î¿Î½|strong="G2962"\w* \w á¼¡Î¼á¿¶Î½|strong="G1473"\w*, \w á¼¸Î·ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦Î½|strong="G2424"\w* \w Î§ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„ÏŒÎ½|strong="G5547"\w*, \w á¼Î½|strong="G1722"\w* \w á¼€Ï†Î¸Î±ÏÏƒÎ¯á¾³|strong="G0861"\w*. \w á¼ˆÎ¼Î®Î½|strong="G0281"\w*.\f + \fr 6:24 \ft Î±Î¼Î·Î½ \+bd f\+bd*\+sup 35\+sup* [97%] RP,HF,OC,TR,CP Â¦ â€” ğ•»\+sup 46\+sup*â„µA,B [3%] NU\f*\sup ,\sup*\f + \fr 6:24 \ft The citation of \+bd f\+bd*\+sup 35\+sup* is based on thirty-seven MSSâ€”18, 35, 201, 204, 328, 386, 394, 444, 604, 757, 824, 928, 986, 1072, 1075, 1100, 1248, 1249, 1503, 1548, 1617, 1637, 1725, 1732, 1761, 1855, 1864, 1865, 1892, 1897, 2080, 2352, 2431, 2466, 2554, 2587 and 2723â€”all of which I collated myself. 928, 1864, 2554 and 2723 are â€˜perfectâ€™ representatives of \+bd f\+bd*\+sup 35\+sup* in Ephesians, as they stand, as were the exemplars of another ten. The uniformity is impressive. Since these MSS come from all over the Mediterranean world (Sinai, Jerusalem, Patmos, Constantinople, Bucharest, Aegean, Trikala, Meteora, Athens, Mt. Athos [eight different monasteries], Grottaferrata, Vatican, etc.) they are certainly representative of the family, giving us the precise family profileâ€”it is reflected in the Text without exception. In the statements of evidence I have included the percentage of manuscript attestation for each variant, within either ( ) or [ ]. I have used ( ) for the evidence taken from \+it TuT\+it*, which I take to be reasonably precise. For the variant sets that are not covered there I had to revert to von Soden and the apparatus of N-A\+sup 27\+sup*, supplementing from other sources where possible (Scrivener and Tischendorf)â€”the percentages offered, I have used [ ] for these, are extrapolations based on a comparison of these sources. I venture to predict, if complete collations ever become available, that for any non-Byzantine variants listed with 5 to 1% support (in my apparatus) the margin of error should not exceed Â±1%; for non-Byzantine variants listed with 10 to 6% support the margin of error should hardly exceed Â±3%; where there is some division among the Byzantine witnesses the margin of error should rarely exceed Â±15%. However, I guarantee the witness of Family 35. Please see the last footnote for Matthew for further information.\f*
